name: Sakagura
address: 211 E 43rd St B1, New York, NY 10017, USA

reviews.text: Don't come to Sakagura for your birthday unless you're looking to get BAITED. We came here for my friend's birthday and unfortunately ended the experience on a sour note. This is because my friend placed a reservation on RESY and said that we'd be there for her special day. After eating and waiting for the check, they surprised my friend by giving her a birthday dessert: 3 scoops of black sesame ice cream. We were happy and expected it to be on the house. When we received the bill, they charged us for the dessert that we did NOT ask for. We were dumbfounded that they'd charge us for something without asking if we'd want it while being transparent about fees.

It's in the basement of a building so there's no cell service.
The food is delicious - I think the sashimi is some of the best I've ever had. The shrimp tempura soba was also delicious!

On the very pricey side. I love sushi. This is were refined and specia restaurantl but still It came below my expectations for the prices and the super tiny portions. And this is coming from someone that doesn't like big portions in restaurants. The service was mediocre. The person who served us was probably new and didn't make too much of an effort to explain some things to someone who visited first time.
Always. Always. Good.

This restaurant is incredible. Walk downstairs and youâ€™re transported into an entirely new world. Feels super culturally authentic. Service was incredible. Staff was very kind, knowledgeable, and conversational. Karma was an amazing host and waiter. Thank you Sakagura!!!
Very cool place to impress your friends from out of town. Delicious food and great atmosphere, but pricey for the portions. Definitely more of a special occasion or expense account kind of place.
One of the best in Manhattan.
Quiet place. Try the Donguri and Tataki kyuri

Such a lowkey restaurant but the ambience is amazing. Our waiter was lovely, explained everything thoroughly and gave great suggestions. The food, although small portions was very tasty and authentic. Loved my experience here.
Interesting concept underground! No signal but thereâ€™s WiFi
Hands down one of the best sashimi Iâ€™ve had outside Japan. Worth a special trip.

It has a more upscale setting compared to a typical izakaya, and they offer a wide selection of sake. A LOT!!!
Thereâ€™s only a small sign â€” but Google Maps takes you right to the spot.
The food is good - definitely one of the better Japanese restaurants in the city. Itâ€™s a shame that it has a poor sanitary score so we stopped going. I wish one day they can clean things up!
Had Miguel as a server and he was fantastic. Great food and amazing drinks.

The food here keeps me coming back for more. My friend and I split this dish. Staff members show exceptional attention to needs. Despite limited size, it feels cozy, with fairly friendly service. I'm planning another meal here shortly.
LOVED the soft shell crab and the mishimi Wagyu beef tataki!
I loved the decor and vibe, food was good and the daily lunch is such a good deal ! Vibe felt kind of Midtown lol but I think that was it was lunch

We dined here last night with a couple friend. The service was pretty non existent with language barrier, the chairs very uncomfortable, very dark, the plates are tiny, they donâ€™t serve sushi for dinner. The sake they recommended that tasted like â€œSauvignon blancâ€ tasted nothing like that for $48/glass. Will not return.
Obviously the food is delicious. Definitely not somewhere I'd come every month. The prices are high just as every other NYC restaurant. The staff were friendly and helpful.

Quality Japanese restaurant in NYC

âœ”ï¸ Iâ€™ve been here twice. I ordered Kamo Namban soba (duck and leek) and Hayashi rice. Both were very authentic.

âœ”ï¸ Service and atmosphere

âœ”ï¸ Very reasonable and quality lunch option at 18 USD with limited availability. I tried Hayashi rice on Monday and it was delicious!

I arrived without a reservation for a dinner for two. The place didnâ€™t seem busy, and my guest and I approached knowing they would be closing in about an hour and a half.

Everything seemed fine at first, but from the beginning, the service was completely disappointing. The server only approached the table to mention the specials. When my guest asked a question about the menu, he responded in a rather condescending tone that the item was â€œonly available at lunch,â€ without offering any alternatives. That immediately made me feel like we were in the wrong place and that the restaurant had nothing else to offer. When we mentioned we wouldnâ€™t be drinking and would just have water, he gave us a look as if we had insulted him. After that, the server never returned to our table.

In fact, it was the manager who ended up taking my order. He was polite and answered a question that the server had avoided entirelyâ€”simply asking for the Wi-Fi password.

The dishes started to arrive, but the back servers seemed to be pretending to be busy, even though the restaurant clearly wasnâ€™t. As soon as a dish was finishedâ€”no matter how smallâ€”it was immediately taken away. At one point, a back server actually moved my guestâ€™s plate while he was still eating. We looked at each other in disbelief, wondering, â€œIs this really happening?â€

When clearing the last course, in his rush to clean the table, one back server made a mess and actually spilled a dish of soy sauce on my clothes. He handed me paper napkins, which obviously did little to help.

The entire time, I never saw the server again until I placed my card on the table and asked for the check from a distance. After everything, he casually asked, â€œHow was everything?â€â€”to which I replied, â€œIt was a disaster.â€ I had come after work to relax and enjoy a nice dinner with someone, but instead, it turned into an unpleasant experience. I left smelling like soy sauce, and after giving him my card, I waited ten minutes to get it back.

The manager returned it, apologizing and offering a 20% discount as compensation. I left that amount as the tipâ€”not because the service deserved it (it absolutely didnâ€™t), but simply because I wanted to pay and leave. The truth is, this place ruined my evening.

I wouldnâ€™t return, not even if I were invited.

This is the kind of place for people who donâ€™t care about details, are used to eating in a rush, and donâ€™t mind having their plates moved while theyâ€™re still eating. I came in with high expectations and left with the impression of extremely mediocre service.
Iâ€™m from Japan. I loved the bathroom.
down under the street... good atmosphere and food...

Nestled beneath an ordinary Midtown office building lies Sakagura, a refined Tokyo-style izakaya and sake bar that feels like a secret sanctuary in Manhattan  . If you really want to enjoy an authentic Japanese New York City gem ğŸ’ ğŸ—½ ğŸ£ ğŸ¶. MUST COME ! The manager Alex , Miguel and Herman the best of the best !

åœ°ä¸‹ã®ä»„æš—ã„é›°å›²æ°—ã§æ·±ã„è©±ã¨ã‹ã‚‚ã§ããã†ã€‚ã“ã£ã¡ã«ã¯å‹ã ã¡ã„ãªã„ã‹ã‚‰ãã‚“ãªæ©Ÿä¼šã¯ãªã„ã‘ã©ã€‚

My boyfriend took me to Sakagura for my 30th birthday, and it was one of the most memorable dining experiences Iâ€™ve hadâ€”not just in New York, but anywhere in the U.S. Weâ€™ve spent time in Japan, and this meal genuinely transported us back. It was the first time since moving to NYC that I felt Iâ€™d tasted truly authentic Japanese flavors.

We ordered the root vegetable dish, the pork belly, udon noodles, and shared a bottle of yuzu sake. Every bite was incredibly flavorful and beautifully prepared. The balance of textures, the seasoning, and the attention to detail in presentation were exceptional.

Service was equally impressiveâ€”Miguel, our captain for the evening, was warm, knowledgeable, and made us feel incredibly welcome. All the servers were attentive and kind, and even called my boyfriend the next day after he accidentally left his headphones behind. Such a thoughtful touch!

The ambiance deserves its own praise. When we first arrived, we walked through a lobby and then descended a narrow staircase. I have to admit, I was wondering where on earth we were goingâ€”but then the space opened up into a stunning, serene room with soft lighting and beautiful Japanese-inspired design. It felt like a hidden gem tucked away from the noise of the city.

This place is truly special. Whether youâ€™ve been to Japan and are looking to relive those culinary memories, or youâ€™re just seeking an exceptional meal in NYC, Sakagura is not to be missed.

Food was decent, but the service was all over the place. The hostesses were attentive and friendly. Our waiter had more of a "no-nonsense" attitude that you'd expect more at a 24-hour diner than a restaurant like this. My sashimi and soup combo came without soy sauce or a spoon. I eventually got both after flagging down another server, but the soy sauce was taken away the second I finished my last piece of fishâ€”no â€œMay Iâ€ or â€œDo you mind?â€ Just gone. Itâ€™s the little things that count, and the service missed the mark there.

If I could give this place more than five stars, I would the staff was amazing. The place was just off the charts. The food was great fair prices for what you are given. I would come here for lunch and dinner. The sushi rolls are amazing. The tempura was amazing. I would definitely come here for a date meetings, friendly dates whatever kind of dates so I would bring anyone here for any kind of occasion they did an amazing job. I would recommend to reserve
En el subsuelo de un edificio,  mÃ¡gico lugar, excelente atenciÃ³n y comida suprema!

Sadly, the atmosphere was the only perk here. It used to have a wide variety of selection for sashimi and other plates but not anymore. Hope this photo helps to guide others with what to expect with portion and quality. I think we paid $120 for all of this and 2 draft beer!

I miss the days when Sakagura felt truly special, both in experience and menu. In the past few years theyâ€™ve replaced their traditional Japanese menu with what feels like more generic crowd pleasers like fried chicken, pork belly, etc. Their snow crab rice used to be a standout dish with large, succulent pieces of crab in a bowl of fluffy white rice, but theâ€™ve replaced it with a small bowl of rice with shredded crab on par with what you might find at any Japanese restaurant in any neighborhood. The dining room, which used to feel like stepping into a magical garden, has been renovated to feel like a more generic Japanese restaurant. The food is still good but maybe not worth the price points anymore. Sake list is still strong, and service impeccable. Definitely miss the pre-2020 Sakagura.

The food and sake pairing recommended by our waiter was incredible (they also have limited but decent wine options - I had a delicious chablis). Food wise, we had the 5-type sashimi starter, black cod and pork belly for mains, and macha tiramisu and sorbet for dessert - all incredible. First dinner on this trip to NY and it hit all the right notes. Our waiters were very attentive and friendly. Overall lovely space with good energy, would definitely come back!
Sat at the bar.

Extremely expensive and average
Definitely not worth the price or seeking it out.
Doesn't deserve the Michelin rating.
We had multiple apps and yakitori with maim dishes
You will be sorry
I keep coming back here. Awesome food (particularly the sashimi) and energy. The sake bar is great to sit at
Simply the best
Its kinda overprice for me but i know why, all the servers and waiters is so nice. The food is so good but its a place to eat when you have special occasion for me

A hidden and underrated spot with exquisite Japanese foodâ€”some of the best Iâ€™ve ever had.

Everything we ateâ€”from the sushi to the miso dengaku to the ice cold sobaâ€”was fantastic: perfect and elevated renditions of classic dishes.

Itâ€™s a bit hard to find, tucked away in a basement location with minimal signage, but the setting is quite nice and the service is attentive.

Perhaps the best hidden gem Iâ€™ve stumbled upon. Highly recommended.
Sushi wasnâ€™t available to order Monday nights. Atmosphere was amazing and entrance truly felt hidden away in Midtown.
Decent midtown restaurant. Not worth traveling to
amazing food and service!
Not cheap but they all tastes authentic.

Can't speak enough of the sushi experience I had here.  The presentation was about as Instagram worthy as you can get, and the taste and freshness were amongst the best I've ever had.  As a frequent traveler, I had a suitcase of which they offered to store for me without any ask from me.  The staff were ALL beyond attentive and extremely friendly. Both myself and my friend were treated as well as anyone could expect from a dining experience.  This was my first visit, but I can guarantee you there will be many more.   Five star first class all around here.
The restaurant was out of lunch specials on a Friday at 1225pmâ€¦ Also asked for the dessert menu and received the check instead. Oh the food was fine and so was the ambiance.
Great place. Food is great. Service is very careful. Wide choice of sakes. We were there three adults and 2 teens. Great experience. I've been in this place many times. It never disappoints.

202504

ãƒ‹ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ¨ãƒ¼ã‚¯ã§æœ¬æ ¼çš„ãªå±…é…’å±‹æ–™ç†ã¨ãŠã„ã—ã„æ—¥æœ¬é…’ãŒæ¥½ã—ã‚ã‚‹ã‚ˆ
Service was really good

True hidden gem!

Sakagura delivers an authentic and elevated Japanese dining experience thatâ€™s hard to find.
Tucked away beneath the city streets, this cozy izakaya-style spot surprises you the moment you walk in. The seafood is incredibly fresh, and the miso cod is an absolute must-haveâ€”flaky, flavorful, and perfectly cooked.

The izakaya selections are top-tier, offering both classic dishes and inventive small plates that pair beautifully with their extensive sake menu. The ambiance strikes the perfect balance between relaxed and refined, and the service was warm, attentive, and knowledgeable without ever feeling rushed.

If youâ€™re a fan of Japanese cuisine (or just good food), Sakagura is a destination worth discovering.

Semi-high-end Japanese restaurant prepared with great lists of sake and speakeasy kinda vibe.

Been here 5-6 times over past 10 years so not many times, but never had any dissappointing experiences so far; well served varieties of foods were always delicious, sake choices were great match with the foods, and the fact that this is probably one of very few places in NYC (if not only) with Japanese style speakeasy kinda vibe adds bit of excitement when visiting. This will be great place for those who like Japanese foods and most likely will serve well for any types of special occassions. Just make sure you make your reservation.

FYI, if you look at the first floor of this building, you might not be able to straightforwardly recognize that the building is where Sakagura is located because the 1st floor looks very empty. You have to get into the building and Sakagura is at downstairs.

Hidden in the basement of a bustling commercial building, feels like a secret haven. Stepping inside, youâ€™re transported into the warm ambiance of a Japanese izakaya. With an extensive selection of sake and a diverse menu, itâ€™s a place that invites you to linger. The sashimi, Toro, tempura, and grilled dishes are all exquisitely prepared, offering an authentic taste of Japan. We celebrated Christmas here with friends, sharing drinks and reflecting on the year gone by and the year ahead. Sakagura is not just about the food; itâ€™s a perfect spot for gatherings with the right people and ambiance.

I was brought by a friend to this Japanese restaurant which is located in a basement of an office building. It was dark inside. The food was delicious and had unique flavor. Especially I liked the grilled cod and lightly seared beef. Theyâ€¦

Great lunch on Friday especially on their house made fresh soba noodle.
Also my colleague had an excellent sushi set and cold sake this afternoon.
Kubota Jukai Daiginjo was the way to go with sushi and soba noodles
You may need to find this â€œExcellent Japanese restaurantâ€™s rather small sign at entrance and restaurant is in downstairs of Midtown office buildingâ€.

impeccable service in an intimate space ripe for catching up with friends. great sake recommenations from our server and delicious sashimi, karaage, scallop, and udon. the sweet potato beer is a bit sweet go for wheat next time

Amazing place, unique food, cool ambiance. I have been coming here for years and it is still really good and really popular. Highly recommend their soba noodles, I tried Nameko, which was superb. The scallop appetizer is really. Sesame cheesecake was fantastic, simple, and super tasty.

I was intrigued by the speakeasy vibe and hidden location. The flavors were good but sadly I came hungry and left hungry. We spent 130 with tip for two people. The prices appeared reasonable on the rather confusing menu, but when the dishes came they were fit in your palm tiny. That made the prices very high for what you get. I had three tiny slices of scallops on my â€œseafoodâ€ while my wife got probably a nice half pound of fried chicken. The menu is not clearly divided into starters, mains, etc, and it is a wasnâ€™t clear how much food weâ€™d be getting. It would be nice to have a pot of rice to fill in the gaps. The one Caucasian server lost patience with us and handed us over to a nice Japanese server who carefully explained everything. Service was attentive. Prices on sake run from 17 per carafe to over 1000 per bottle.

Absolutely delicious and authentic Japanese food in a lovely space with impeccable service and an excellent sake selection. Came here for a prix fixe birthday party and was thoroughly impressed. I feel like this spot should have a Michelin star!

Good service and atmosphere. We got the five kind sashimi where all the fish was fresh (except the hokkaido uni which they end up replacing with a different fish), grilled black cod which was too greasy and did not taste fresh and I couldn't finish it. The vegetarian udon and tomago were good.

Romantic valentine dinner at the classy Sakagura restaurant in New York City with amazing nama sake, imported sashimi from Japan, buttery soft wagyu beef, beautiful matcha tirimasu and more ğŸ¥°. Last but not least is the wonderful manager, Alex, who always attentive and made sure we got a great table!

A hidden gem in NY! No signs outside to find this restaurant at the basement of a building.   Great atmosphere with a focus on Japanese authentic food and a wide variety of sake. Most of the dishes we ordered were delicious but the calamari was dry. The four fish sashimi (albeit overpriced) was great except one of them being so so. The egg dish and the fried chicken were tasty. If you like Japanese cooking, this is the place to go.
We celebrated my husband's birthday here. We were completely pleased with the food though would have been happy for less pricey. All the dishes were excellent. We had a great dinner.

Absolutely fantastic! The service is top-notch, the food is incredibleâ€”every dish is flavorful and beautifully presented. Even the washrooms are sparkling clean!

One of the best restaurants Iâ€™ve been to. A must-visit and highly recommended!

Great little place tucked away in a hidden entrance. Immediately youâ€™re hit with the unique ambiance. The interior design is on point. I was here with two friends. The staff were friendly and the food was incredible. The sashimi was freshâ€¦

Highly recommend the Una Ju (Grilled Eel over rice), though a little pricey. Some of their drinks are also quite unique. Service could be a little better - we waited quite a while before our server came over to take our orders, otherwise the rest of the service was prompt. Cozy atmosphere under an office building.

One of the very best Japanese restaurants in the city. Expensive. Melt in your mouth Sashimi. We came for lunch with a party of twelve and tried many dishes, mostly excellent. Only the veggie udon was boring. All the sushi and sashimi we tried were fresh, delicate and delicious.

Excellente adresse pour manger japonais ! On nous a expliquÃ© la carte avec patience, service attentionnÃ©, plats typiques dÃ©licieux, lieu incroyable (au sous-sol dâ€™un immeuble, un peu comme un speakeasy en restaurantâ€¦). On peut manger Ã  table ou au bar mais il faut rÃ©server !

This placeâ€™s best quality is the ambiance! Hidden away, it opens up as a speakeasy. We had a great time here but would have liked a bit more of guidance on what to order, as the dishes are truly complex and we clearly did not know what to order. The desserts are were a highlight! Would not have the onigiri again as they didnâ€™t have a lot of the topping. The wagyu beef was insane!
Fun, speakeasy-Japanese in midtown east. Was super busy on a Sat night. Food is tasty.  Pretty impressive sake list. Team couldâ€™ve been a little more engaged. The shrimp fritters were a standout.

This is what you come to New York for: perfect Japanese food in the basement of an apartment building in the middle of Manhattan.

No signs, no way of knowing itâ€™s there if you havenâ€™t been tipped off, the most elaborate sake menu Iâ€™ve seen since being in Tokyo and food that taste just like it did in Japan.

The ambiance of the place is lovely tooâ€” as is the transition from the heavily lit lobby of the apartment building down a flight of stairs that is half way between NYC and Tokyo to a full immersion into Tokyo, complete with cherry blossoms.

Everything on the menu looked great and given the location, right next to the UN, the prizes are reasonable. We had the udon noodles, edamame beans, and a rice soup bowl. To top it all off we shared the sesame cheesecake with matcha, which was as good as it sounds.

I canâ€™t wait to go back and try all the other items on the menu and surprise people, as I feel Sakagura invented a travel portal that links Japan to the USâ€”and kept it a secret for a select few.

pretty big restaurant in the basement. but we were able to call shortly before we arrived to kind of reserve a spot. Service was really good - the servers are really friendly.
The pork belly is sooo soft and tender. The karage is probably one of the better value dishes. The food in general is really good, but is pretty pricey for their serving sizes. I also thought the summer soba was very yummy.

There are lots of drinks here too, so come if you want to explore some sake!

Very friendly service though slow. We spent more time waiting for service than eating or drinking. I really appreciated the sake list which was priced by cup, carafe, and bottle. They also had good descriptions and tasting notes. The food was good. The wagyu hot stone dish was fun and smelled great.

Located in the basement, this small sake bar. Has a large number of Japanese tapa style small dishes and sushi for you to try. Service is a little sparse but the food comes in waves. Good hybrid and hot dishes; have had better sushi elsewhere though. Good sake though. I did like the seaweed salad which was great with a different twist than the normal version adding a sesame vinagrette and the stamina soba was good mix of ingredients, too. Miso/yuzu cod was excellent, and the desserts didn't appeal much to me.

They do have lunch specials, too, though get there early - they are busy!

The food here was astonishingly good despite most of the menu being devoted to sake selections. The restaurant is barely a sushi restaurant given that most of the choices are cooked dishes. However, the chefâ€™s choice sashimi was outstanding as was everything else we tried. The restaurant itself is very dark and had the speakeasy vibe going. We thoroughly enjoyed our evening and will definitely return the next time we are in New York to try other menu items that we were too full to order the first time.

Sakagura in New York City is an absolute culinary delight, seamlessly blending traditional Japanese flavors with a contemporary dining experience. From the moment you step inside, the ambiance exudes an authentic izakaya charm, creating a unique and immersive atmosphere.

What sets Sakagura apart is its meticulous dedication to authenticity. The menu showcases a carefully curated selection of Japanese dishes, each crafted with precision and presented as a work of art. The izakaya-style dining adds a social and communal aspect, enhancing the overall experience.

Sakagura's extensive sake collection is a testament to its commitment to providing an exceptional journey through Japanese beverages. The knowledgeable staff contributes to the welcoming atmosphere, making each visit an educational and enjoyable exploration of Japanese culinary delights.

In summary, Sakagura is a culinary gem in the heart of New York, offering a refined and genuine taste of Japanese cuisine. It stands as a beacon of cultural richness, inviting patrons to savor the essence of Japan in a sophisticated and memorable setting.

Amazing atmosphere and great food. Only downside that it's underground and there is zero cell service. The free wifi helps stay connected but I think they want you to focus on the food and people you're with :)

Happy hour menu was good and staff was helpful to give tips on how to navigate the extensive drink menu and food items.
